messages: cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (18:26): hmm it's easy to make firefox hang by doing an arc() with a very high number for the radius argument
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (18:28): the CAPTCHA thing makes one go "hmm": http://www.webvisum.com/
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (18:31): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0: icon.png deployed on validator.nu. the usual front page caching issues apply.
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (18:31): hendry: see above. validator.nu now has a favicon
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (18:34): the V is a bit blurry but i guess it's ok
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (18:35): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0: I deployed your file bit-for-bit :-)

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (18:43): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: i argue that a benevolent dictator is needed for good work to result, and point to tim as an example of the w3c having a benevolent dictator. but the w3c has been doing poor work in recent years, which would be explained by tim no longer being dictator as per that post.
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (18:43): learns the term syntactic vinegar from tantek's namespaces considered harmful wiki article

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (18:44): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: it seems though, that actually using the term "benevolent dictator" is a PR problem when your audience hasn't been socialized to know Python terminology
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (18:44): (both for the W3C and the WHATWG)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (18:44): python has a benevolent dictator?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (18:44): cool
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (18:44): i guess i knew that
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (18:45): that certainly isn't where i first heard the term
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (18:45): for life even
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (18:45): but yes, most big projects have one
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (18:45): linux, perl, python
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (18:45): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: having one and using the term without PR issues are two different things
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (18:46): *shrug*
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (18:46): the term is accurate
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (18:46): i'm not big into doublespeak
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (18:46): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: I don't follow Linux development, but I'd expect certain vendors to be able to override Linus if Linus wanted bad things
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (18:47): no more so than in python, as far as i can tell
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:48): I would guess that far more vendors ship the Linux kernel with significant patches than for Python

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (18:48): the PR issue is that people who aren't familiar with the concept think that the dictator can dictate anything (one person's opinion) when really the dictator can only dictate things that implementors allow the dictator to resolve
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:49): so they have ultimate control over what their users run
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (18:51): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: that isn't a problem with the term "dictator", it's a problem with the word "spec".
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (18:51): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: c.f. the people who think the vendors should do whatever the wg resolves.
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (18:52): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: that, too

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (18:53): I wonder where the supposed expert were expected to come from according to the writer of the blog post from a few days ago that advocated experts instead of browser vendors driving the spec
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:54): What are they meant to be experts in?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (18:54): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: I don't know. They'd be experts.
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (19:01): someone should write up some theory with words like "indifference curve" explaining what kind of things in practice can be decided by whom
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:02): Might be easier to understand if it didn't use words like "indifference curve" :-)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (19:05): fwiw, I think both "dictator" and "consensus" give the wrong idea of how things really happen
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (19:19): I wonder if I get accused of being part of a vast browser-wing conspiracy if I blog about managing one's expectations when suggesting features for Web specs
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (19:21): one thing that intrigues me is how socialization happens when a new person approaches a group like the WHATWG
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (19:21): sounds useful to blog about that
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (19:22): makes things easier when someone new comes along :)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (19:22): I mean: why is it that some people fit the group but some people feel frustrated that they aren't being listened to
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (19:22): do people get socialized
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (19:23): or do the opinions a person happens to hold when approaching the group predetermine if the person fits in?

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (19:33): do we have any documentation that indicates that "try to get a browser vendor to commit to implementing it experimentally" should be read the same way "patches welcome" should be read in an open source context?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:39): i.e. "shut up and don't come back until you've done something productive"?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:42): It would be nicer if they weren't told to go away, even in politer language
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (20:06): waves
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (20:09): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: Hello
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (20:10): Onboard train internet access is so slow :(
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (20:10): and I keep getting errors trying to push the changes I made to the spec-ge
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (20:10): *gen
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (20:11): Probably contention from all the passengers running BitTorrent
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (20:11): Got up to 12KB/s! New high!
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (20:11): It wasn't this bad last time :\
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (20:13): Oh, well, it's not got as bad as it was when I was stuck outside Inverkeithing in May: highest was 51 _BYTES_ per second.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (20:13): I was trying to download a bit of the Unicode spec at the time. It was estimating several hours remaining. For a single chapter.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (20:14): looks at his Downloads window
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (20:14): 1323.7 KByte/s for the last thing I downloaded, which sounds much more reasonable
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (20:14): WHAT!? Peak it now 35KB/s! That's amazing!
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (20:15): (the highest I've ever got on a train would be maybe 300KB/s)
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (20:16): sighs
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (20:16): I _can't_ get a connection that fast at home

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (20:33): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: i certainly don't mean "don't come back until you've done something productive"; we've had input from many people who have done nothing but make a suggestion, and that's absolutely fine

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (20:34): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: however, when someone is told "we have considered that and rejected it because browser vendors won't implement it" and they argue back, then the real honest answer is "well then get a browser vendor to implement it"
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (20:35): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: it's not a lie, it's not even misleading

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (20:35): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: however, it's possible that some people do come to a working group like the whatwg with expectations that don't match what will happen (e.g. expecting suggestions to be considered without looking at previous existing content)

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (20:36): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: (or not accepting that simplicity is a virtue for the web platform, or that a significant number of web developers will just copy and paste anything until it works)
7b9920d3e896b22057673a1c887015a7 (20:56): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, does the "Server-sent DOM Events" section still need "DOM" in the title?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (20:56): i guess not
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (21:06): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: I wasn't suggesting that the "experimental implementation" line were a lie or misleading.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:06): sure
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (21:07): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: and suggestions are fine too
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (21:08): after all, I don't have commit access to any browser code base
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (21:08): I suggest stuff, though
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (21:08): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, "websocket-uri" is obviously the wrong name! :)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (21:09): but I try not to act like I were entitled to get other implement my suggestions right away
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (21:09): s/other/others/
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (21:10): actually, I think the key to not getting too frustrated is not expecting to be entitled to swift implmentation in browsers
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (21:15): what's the dictator blog post?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (21:15): b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f: http://www.w3.org/QA/2008/06/what_benevolent_dictator.html
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:20): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: what should it be called instead (other than URL)?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (21:21): URL is not an option?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:22): i might change it to URL, but that's not a good name either :-)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (21:23): Hmm. the complexity of http://juicystudio.com/wcag/tables/complexdatatable.html is that the dataset is three-dimensional, isn't it?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (21:23): actually, that's not exactly it
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (21:24): anyway, the table isn't immediately obvious even visually

edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (21:24): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, I suggest URL until something better comes up. Especially since we try to remove URI everywhere introducing it here is just confusing :)
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (21:25): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, maybe location
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (21:25): though given that it holds a URL...
